review.title: Studying the Wikipedia Hyperlink Graph for Relatedness and Disambiguation
review.abstract: Hyperlinks and other relations in Wikipedia are a extraordinary resource which is still not fully understood. In this paper we study the different types of links in Wikipedia, and contrast the use of the full graph with respect to just direct links. We apply a well-known random walk algorithm on two tasks, word relatedness and named-entity disambiguation. We show that using the full graph is more effective than just direct links by a large margin, that non-reciprocal links harm performance, and that there is no benefit from categories and infoboxes, with coherent results on both tasks. We set new state-of-the-art figures for systems based on Wikipedia links, comparable to systems exploiting several information sources and/or supervised machine learning. Our approach is open source, with instruction to reproduce results, and amenable to be integrated with complementary text-based methods.

metadata.title: Studying the Wikipedia Hyperlink Graph for Relatedness and Disambiguation

sections.text: Hyperlinks and other relationships in Wikipedia are an extraordinary resource that is still not fully understood. In this paper, we examine the different types of links in Wikipedia and contrast the use of the full chart with direct links. We apply a known random algorithm to two tasks, namely word relevance and entity clarification. We show that using the full chart is more effective than just direct links by a wide margin, that non-reciprocal links impair performance, and that there is no benefit from categories and info boxes, with coherent results for both tasks. We set new numbers for systems based on Wikipedia links, comparable to systems that use multiple sources of information and / or supervised machine learning. Our approach is open source, with instructions to reproduce results, and able to be integrated with complementary text-based methods.

sections.heading: 3 Building Wikipedia Graphs
sections.text: Considering a Wikipedia dump (a snapshot of April 4, 2013), we can find links between articles and category pages, as well as links between category pages (the category structure). Our diagrams contain a directed edge from one article to another if the text of the first article contains a hyperlink to the second article. In addition, we also include hyperlinks in info boxes. The graph contains two types of nodes (articles and categories) and three types of directed edges: hyperlinks from article to article (H), infobox links from article to article (I), links from article to category and links from category to category (C). We have constructed several graphics that use different combinations of nodes and edges. In addition to the directed versions (D), we also have an undirected version of articles (U), and a reduced graphic that contains only links that are reciproactive.

sections.heading: 3.1 Building the dictionary
sections.text: To link running text to the articles in the graph, we use a dictionary, i.e. a static association between mentions with all sorts of articles that the mention can refer to. We have created our dictionary from the same Wikipedia dump, with article titles, redirects, clarification pages and anchor text. Mention strings are lowercase and any text between brackets is removed. If an anchor points to a clarification page, the text is associated with all sorts of articles that the clarification page refers to. Any association between a mention and an article is evaluated with the previous probability, estimated as the number of times the mention occurs in an anchor divided by the scale edges and could otherwise be avoided.

sections.heading: 4 Random Walks
sections.text: The PageRank Random Walk Algorithm (Brin and Page, 1998) is a method of ranking vertices in a chart according to their relative structural significance. PageRank can be considered the result of a random walk process in which the final rank of the node i represents the probability of a random path across the graph ending on node i, at a sufficiently large time.Personalized PageRank (PPR) is a variant of the PageRank (Haveliwala, 2002), in which the user's query defines the importance of each node, distorting the resulting PageRank value to favor nodes near the query nodes. Query distortion is also called a teleport vector. PPR has been successfully used on the WordNet chart for relativity (Hughes and Ramage, 2007; Agirre et al., 2010) and Wre (Agiret, 2014) Soroa.

sections.heading: 8 Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: This work differs from previous work based on Wikipedia and Derived Resources in that it focuses on a single source of knowledge (links in Wikipedia) with a clear research objective: faced with a well-established random algorithm, we have examined which sources of links and filtering methods are useful, contrasting the use of the full diagram with the use of only direct links. We follow a clear development / testing / analysis method based on a wide range of both relations and NED datasets. All software and data are publicly available, with instructions for out-of-the-box replicability.

metadata.abstractText: Hyperlinks and other relations in Wikipedia are a extraordinary resource which is still not fully understood. In this paper we study the different types of links in Wikipedia, and contrast the use of the full graph with respect to just direct links. We apply a well-known random walk algorithm on two tasks, word relatedness and named-entity disambiguation. We show that using the full graph is more effective than just direct links by a large margin, that non-reciprocal links harm performance, and that there is no benefit from categories and infoboxes, with coherent results on both tasks. We set new state-of-the-art figures for systems based on Wikipedia links, comparable to systems exploiting several information sources and/or supervised machine learning. Our approach is open source, with instruction to reproduce results, and amenable to be integrated with complementary text-based methods.
